fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: Cineworld says sequels will be good for box office Cineworld cheered investors yesterday by predicting that 2007 earnings would be towards the top of analysts' expectations. The 73-strong cinema chain said 2008 had started well thanks to the popularity of I Am Legend. "The outlook for 2008 looks promising, with a compelling line-up of proven film franchises which include The Chronicles of Narnia, Batman, The Mummy, Harry Potter, Star Trek, James Bond and a new instalment of Indiana Jones," it added. Cineworld's shares slumped last month after it said Carlton Screen Advertising wanted to amend the terms of their contract. Katie Allen GCap's board director Steve Orchard quits The radio group GCap is parting company with its board member and operations director, Steve Orchard, after he lost out to his colleague Fru Hazlitt in the race for the chief executive's job. Orchard's departure from the owner of Classic FM and Capital comes ahead of Hazlitt's game plan for the business, which will be revealed on February 11. Investors will be eager to see how she plans to ensure GCap can prosper after it rejected a bid from its rival Global Radio. Orchard, who began as a reporter on Wiltshire Radio, was on the board of GWR when it merged with Capital Radio to form GCap in 2005. Katie Allen Cadbury Schweppes sells Monkhill to Tangerine Cadbury Schweppes has agreed to sell the Yorkshire sweets business behind Barratt's Sherbet Fountains and Butterkist popcorn to the Blackpool-based sweets group Tangerine, makers of Mojo penny chews, for £58m. Monkhill Confectionery includes factories in York, Cleckheaton and Pontefract, as well as a distribution centre near Chesterfield in Derbyshire. A spokesman for the new owner, which has factories in Liverpool, Poole and two in Blackpool, said there were no plans for closures or job losses. Like Monkhill, much of Tangerine's manufacturing is for supermarkets' own-label sweets. Simon Bowers BAE Systems and QinetiQ go shopping in Australia Two of Britain's defence companies announced Australian acquisitions yesterday. BAE Systems agreed to pay £356m for Tenix Defence, an Australian contractor that provides military vehicles, aircraft system integration and support services, electronics and maritime support. The deal will double BAE's presence in Australia, one of its six home markets, where it will have a workforce of 5,500 and sales of £550m. Separately, QinetiQ Group said it was buying the Melbourne-based company AeroStructures, which provides engineering assessment and aeronautical analysis. Mark Milner
